quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: The Seven Rules of Power, get out of your own way, break the rules, show up in a powerful fashion, create a powerful brand, network relentlessly, use your power, and understand that once you've acquired power, what you did to get there will be forgiven, forgotten, or both.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete, memorable framework practitioners can use as a checklist for building influence and advancing their careers.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: This is not about personality. These are skills they can be mastered.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: Reframes power-building as learnable behaviors rather than innate traits, making it actionable for anyone.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Well, you already have done a fabulous job of illustrating principle one. That is one way to get in our own way. If I think power is dirty, the first thing that's going to happen is I'm not going to do what I need to do to be successful in my career.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: A counterintuitive mindset shift: moral discomfort with power can directly sabotage career success by preventing necessary actions.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: You're not describing how the world should work. This is just how it is.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Sets a pragmatic lens for the episode: focus on reality-based career strategy rather than idealized norms.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: if you want power to be used for good, more good people need to have power.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A values-based rationale for pursuing influence: opting out can leave power concentrated in the wrong hands.

quotes.topic_title: Why power feels uncomfortable, why it matters
quotes.text: Well, it's important because a guy named Gerald Ferris developed a scale of political skill. And he and a bunch of his colleagues over the years did a lot of empirical research that demonstrates that political skill is associated with a lot of positive outcomes, salary, getting promoted, being happy in your career, being happy in your job, being less stressed.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: Grounds the importance of power-building in empirical research and concrete career outcomes practitioners care about.

quotes.topic_title: Why power feels uncomfortable, why it matters
quotes.text: Yeah, so I think it makes people uncomfortable because the realities of what it takes to get power bear almost no resemblance to what you're taught in Sunday school or the mosque or wherever, how your parents raised you. They bear almost no resemblance to how we think the world ought to be.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: Explains the root cause of discomfort as a mismatch between moral upbringing/ideals and real-world power dynamics.

quotes.topic_title: Why power feels uncomfortable, why it matters
quotes.text: But I tell people, I see people with hammers hitting other people on the head. That does not mean that a hammer is not a useful tool.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: Offers a memorable tool-vs-misuse mental model to separate power itself from unethical applications of it.

quotes.topic_title: Why power feels uncomfortable, why it matters
quotes.text: So I think we've confused the tool for how it has been used.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: Summarizes the core reframing: learn power skills without equating them with bad intent or outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Why power feels uncomfortable, why it matters
quotes.text: But these are folks who will not succeed unless they learn power skills, because the world is stacked against them in lots of ways.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: Highlights why underrepresented groups especially benefit from intentionally building power skills as a practical necessity.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With Uizard, I can simply upload my screenshot and Uizard's AI will turn them into a fully editable UI design, that I can then take, make tweaks to, and then share with my teams in minutes.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete workflow for turning feedback screenshots into editable designs quickly to speed up iteration cycles.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And when I want to get really creative and explore totally new ways to improve our product experience, I can use Uizard's AI to generate new design concepts from simple text prompts, and turn them into interactive prototypes effortlessly.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights a practical method for rapid ideation: text prompts to concept generation to prototypes.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: There's a reason that over 2.6 million people have trusted Uizard to accelerate every phase of their product life cycle and speed up time to market.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A specific adoption data point used to support the claim that the tool can accelerate product development.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: We all know that your website shouldn't be a static asset. It should be a dynamic part of your strategy that drives conversions.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A memorable framing that encourages teams to treat the website as an actively optimized growth lever, not a one-and-done deliverable.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: But here's a number for you. 54% of leaders say web updates take too long.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete statistic that quantifies a common bottleneck and motivates investment in faster web iteration.

quotes.topic_title: Being less judgmental to build influence
quotes.text: If you come to the class and you're in that much psychological discomfort, you're not going to learn anything.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: Highlights the practical prerequisite for learning (and influence-building): emotional openness rather than defensive resistance.

quotes.topic_title: Being less judgmental to build influence
quotes.text: If you judge people, you have no time to love them.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: A memorable principle linking judgment to reduced capacity for relationship-building, a core input to influence.

quotes.topic_title: Being less judgmental to build influence
quotes.text: So therefore, you should suspend judgment in the sense that if somebody is on your critical path, the only judgment you should make is they're on my critical path.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: Provides a concrete mental model (“critical path”) for deciding when to set aside personal opinions to get work done through others.

quotes.topic_title: Being less judgmental to build influence
quotes.text: And as I have taught senior executives over the years, it is absolutely clear to me that one of the skills that they have mastered is they have a skill that you cannot tell what they think of you.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: Counterintuitive observation that top leaders manage their emotional leakage to preserve cooperation and influence.

quotes.topic_title: Being less judgmental to build influence
quotes.text: And if I leak out in ways that say I don't respect you or I don't like you, I don't admire you, whatever, my odds of getting you to work productively with me goes essentially to zero.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: Actionable warning that signaling disrespect destroys collaboration, making influence impossible even when you “need” someone.

quotes.topic_title: Seven Rules overview and Doing Power practice
quotes.text: Not everyone we encounter in Paths to Power is someone you're going to want to emulate. This is a class about how to get things done, how to build and wield influence, and there are multiple ways to accomplish these objectives.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A pragmatic framing that separates learning influence tactics from endorsing every role model, expanding the set of viable strategies.

quotes.topic_title: Seven Rules overview and Doing Power practice
quotes.text: the impact I want to have is not to have people like me, but to have that kind of impact. To make people more successful, more effective in their lives.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: A results-over-likability principle that encourages prioritizing effectiveness and real-world outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Seven Rules overview and Doing Power practice
quotes.text: they have to do power. They have to do something during the quarter to take the principles of the class, and what they're learning, and put them into practice.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: A concrete methodology (“Doing Power”) for closing the knowing-doing gap by requiring real-world application.

quotes.topic_title: Seven Rules overview and Doing Power practice
quotes.text: if you don't use what you learn, the learning will disappear.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: Actionable advice to operationalize learning immediately so it sticks rather than decays.

quotes.topic_title: Seven Rules overview and Doing Power practice
quotes.text: And in 2012, his Doing Power project was to get appointed to be Mitt Romney's, it was Mitt Romney was running for president, to be head of economic policy for the Romney campaign. Believe it or not, he was offered the job.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: An extreme case study showing how ambitious “Doing Power” projects can translate classroom principles into high-stakes career opportunities.

quotes.topic_title: Rule: Build a powerful personal brand
quotes.text: There are by definition fewer positions at the top than at the bottom.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: Sets the structural premise (hierarchy + scarcity) that makes deliberate career-advancement tactics necessary.

quotes.topic_title: Rule: Build a powerful personal brand
quotes.text: There are many ways to get promoted, but I will guarantee you one thing, no one is going to promote Lenny if they don't know who the hell you are.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: A blunt, actionable reminder that visibility is a prerequisite for advancement, not a nice-to-have.

quotes.topic_title: Rule: Build a powerful personal brand
quotes.text: So therefore you have to do something to differentiate yourself. You have to build a brand.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: A simple methodology: differentiation is the mechanism by which visibility becomes career leverage.

quotes.topic_title: Rule: Build a powerful personal brand
quotes.text: Tristan Walker began signing up partnerships. So one day the founder says, holy God, he signed up Starbucks. Maybe I ought to hire this guy.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: Concrete example of building a brand through pre-hire impact—creating undeniable proof of value before getting the role.

quotes.topic_title: Rule: Build a powerful personal brand
quotes.text: Obviously there's substance. If you have visibility without substance, people will know you're useless. But if you have substance without visibility, no one will know the substance that you got.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: Memorable mental model for balancing competence and self-presentation: both are required, and either alone fails.

quotes.topic_title: Rule: Get out of your own way
quotes.text: So if I think power is dirty, if I think power is evil, if I think power is something I want nothing to do with, the first thing that's going to happen is I'm not going to do what I need to do to be successful in my career.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: Reframes discomfort with power as a self-sabotaging belief that directly blocks career-advancing actions.

quotes.topic_title: Rule: Get out of your own way
quotes.text: This is called pre-emptory apology. If the comment is not going to be useful, don't say it. That's number one, but number two, don't apologize.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: Gives a concrete behavioral rule to stop undermining your authority in meetings and conversations.

quotes.topic_title: Rule: Get out of your own way
quotes.text: Don't think of yourself as not deserving of the job that you hold, because that attitude will leak out and other people will say, if Lenny doesn't think he deserved the job, then maybe I shouldn't think he deserves the job either.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: Explains a social-perception mechanism: your self-doubt becomes a signal that shapes others’ judgments of your competence.

quotes.topic_title: Rule: Get out of your own way
quotes.text: If you want to be liked, get a dog.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A memorable heuristic for deprioritizing likability as a career strategy in favor of effectiveness.

quotes.topic_title: Rule: Get out of your own way
quotes.text: He's doing microsurgery on my spine, I can wind up permanently paralyzed. I really don't care about his personality. I don't care about his office furniture.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: A high-stakes example that highlights how performance outweighs likability when outcomes matter.

quotes.topic_title: Rule: Break the rules to stand out
quotes.text: Well, for many reasons, number one, when you break the rules, you stand out. You become memorable when you do something that's unexpected. And being memorable is of course important, as we've already discussed.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: A simple cause-effect model: rule-breaking creates memorability, which increases influence.

quotes.topic_title: Rule: Break the rules to stand out
quotes.text: Number two, the rules were made mostly by the people who are favored by the rules in place.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: A contrarian lens for why following norms can keep you disadvantaged in systems designed for incumbents.

quotes.topic_title: Rule: Break the rules to stand out
quotes.text: One of the conventional wisdoms that people I think adhere to way too much, is don't ask. Don't ask, don't ask for help. You need to show self-sufficiency.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: Challenges the common career instinct to appear self-reliant, pointing to asking as an underused power move.

quotes.topic_title: Rule: Break the rules to stand out
quotes.text: And what is the worst that could happen? If you ask and they say, no, you are no worse off than had you not asked in the first place. If you don't ask, you're not going to get it. If you ask and they say, no, you're not going to get it. Get over your ego, ask.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: Actionable advice with a downside-minimization framing that makes asking feel rational and low-risk.

quotes.topic_title: Rule: Break the rules to stand out
quotes.text: He makes a lot of little bets, not a few big bets. He runs a very lean operation. He doesn't have a lot of partners. He doesn't have actually any partners, so he can't be fired by his partners.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: A concrete example of unconventional tactics (portfolio, operating model, governance) used to build power in VC.

quotes.topic_title: Rule: Network relentlessly (and generously)
quotes.text: Will tell you that the first principle of networking is in fact generosity. It's generosity. What can I do for you? How can I be helpful? Who can I introduce you to? Either a company or a product or a person who can be helpful to you in your career.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: Reframes networking from self-promotion to a generosity-first approach with concrete prompts you can use immediately.

quotes.topic_title: Rule: Network relentlessly (and generously)
quotes.text: But in order to be able to introduce you to someone who's going to be useful to you, I have to know people. If I don't know anybody, I can't introduce you to anybody.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: A simple mental model: your ability to create value via introductions is constrained by the breadth of your network.

quotes.topic_title: Rule: Network relentlessly (and generously)
quotes.text: One day I decided to take your class to an extreme. I decided to stop doing my job.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: A counterintuitive story illustrating how prioritizing relationships can outweigh task execution in certain environments.

quotes.topic_title: Rule: Network relentlessly (and generously)
quotes.text: One of the exercises I give my students is I say, write a list of 10 people who, if you knew them and if they knew you, would be important for whatever you're trying to accomplish in your career.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: A practical, repeatable exercise for turning “networking” into a targeted plan tied to career goals.

quotes.topic_title: Rule: Network relentlessly (and generously)
quotes.text: So this is not some icky thing. This is connecting people who benefit from being connected.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: A memorable reframe that reduces “cringe” by defining networking as mutually beneficial brokering.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If you're trying to build that kind of experience for your users, you need up to date, reliable information about what your users do in your product and why they do it.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights the practical requirement of pairing great UX with reliable behavioral data to understand both actions and motivations.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Heap captures all of this user activity for you automatically, and then gives you definitive answers to all your questions about user behavior in seconds, not weeks.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A memorable claim about automating analytics collection and drastically reducing time-to-insight for product decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With Heap, it's easy to prioritize the product investments that improve conversion, engagement and retention.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Connects analytics directly to an actionable prioritization method focused on core growth metrics.

quotes.topic_title: Weak ties and brokerage as networking strategy
quotes.text: So to the extent that you build ties with people who are more different from you in every dimension, you are more likely to learn non-redundant information, and come in contact with people that you don't already know.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: Actionable networking heuristic: deliberately cultivate weak ties with people unlike you to access novel information and new contacts.

quotes.topic_title: Weak ties and brokerage as networking strategy
quotes.text: Mark Granovetter, a sociologist who still teaches at Stanford, wrote a book entitled The Strength of Weak Ties.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: Points to the foundational research framework behind why weak ties can be strategically powerful.

quotes.topic_title: Weak ties and brokerage as networking strategy
quotes.text: And he did a study, I guess it was at that time in Boston. He did a study of job seekers in Massachusetts, and he looked at people who got jobs through applying to ads, through more formal means. And then he looked at people who got jobs through referrals from their network.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: Concrete research setup that contrasts formal job search methods with network-based referrals.

quotes.topic_title: Weak ties and brokerage as networking strategy
quotes.text: And it turns out, of course, the jobs that you get through your network referrals are much better jobs.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: Counterintuitive takeaway: networks outperform formal channels for job quality.

quotes.topic_title: Weak ties and brokerage as networking strategy
quotes.text: And oftentimes the best jobs that people got were referred to them by people that were not particularly close to them.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: Memorable statement capturing the core “weak ties” advantage for accessing top opportunities.

quotes.topic_title: Rule: Use your power to get more power
quotes.text: But part of this is you are put in a position of power. You're put in a position of authority in order to make things happen. So to the extent you mobilize your resources and get things to happen, you'll get more resources.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: Captures the self-reinforcing loop: using authority to deliver outcomes is how you earn additional resources and influence.

quotes.topic_title: Rule: Use your power to get more power
quotes.text: People want to be associated with success. To the extent that you become successful, more people will want to work with you.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: Explains a practical social dynamic: visible wins attract allies and collaborators, compounding your power base.

quotes.topic_title: Rule: Use your power to get more power
quotes.text: Nobody's going to give you a job to do if the last five jobs like that they gave you, you couldn't get done.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: A blunt performance heuristic that links execution track record directly to future opportunities and scope.

quotes.topic_title: Rule: Use your power to get more power
quotes.text: So the more you are able to do, which oftentimes of course requires power and influence, the more you're able to do, the more you'll be asked to do. But better yet, the more resources you'll be given to help you get things done.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: Highlights the compounding mechanism: power enables results, results increase demand for you, and demand unlocks more resources.

quotes.topic_title: Rule: Use your power to get more power
quotes.text: People are attracted to power, you know that.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: A contrarian reminder that displaying power can itself generate followership and influence, independent of formal authority.

quotes.topic_title: Rule: Show up in a powerful fashion
quotes.text: There is some evidence that suggests we respond mostly to how people look, secondarily to how they sound, and by far the least important to the content of what they say.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: A counterintuitive hierarchy of what drives perceived power, emphasizing delivery over substance.

quotes.topic_title: Rule: Show up in a powerful fashion
quotes.text: You can see this by turning on your TV and turning off the sound. Watch the presidential debates with the sound off. They'll be much better.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: A simple, actionable exercise to train yourself to notice the impact of body language and presence.

quotes.topic_title: Rule: Show up in a powerful fashion
quotes.text: And by the way, what Dana Carney will tell you, and what common sense will tell you, is that these are skills that can be mastered.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: Reframes executive presence as learnable skills rather than fixed personality traits.

quotes.topic_title: Rule: Show up in a powerful fashion
quotes.text: When Steve Jobs began, Steve Jobs couldn't convince you to buy water if you were dying of thirst. He could not give a presentation to save his life.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: A vivid example showing that iconic persuasive ability can be developed rather than innate.

quotes.topic_title: Rule: Show up in a powerful fashion
quotes.text: Invading people's personal space. So gentle touching, standing close to someone. We're not talking about sexual touching, we're talking touch on the arm or the shoulder, shaking people's hands.
quotes.speaker: Jeffrey Pfeffer
quotes.context: A concrete (and somewhat provocative) tactic for signaling power through proximity and touch.
